Label: ISIS-2 TOPIST produced electron density profiles, of highest quality (quality flag = 2 and 3 - X. Huang and B. Reinisch (University of MassachusettsLowell)

VariableDescription.Name: ni
VariableDescription.LongDescription: Topside electron density along orbit in cm-3 (Image)
VariableDescription.Header:
# ******************************************************* 
#  WARNING: Increase time period selected for listing. 
# ******************************************************* 
# 
#              ************************************
#              *****    GLOBAL ATTRIBUTES    ******
#              ************************************
#
#     PROJECT                         ISIS>International Satellite for Ionosphere Studies
#                                     NSSDC>Archived Data
#     DISCIPLINE                      Space Physics>Ionospheric Science
#     SOURCE_NAME                     ISIS-2>International Satellite for Ionosphere Studies 1
#     DATA_TYPE                       NEPROF>Density Profiles
#     DESCRIPTOR                      TOPIST>Generated by TOPIST program, quality flags 2 and 3
#     DATA_VERSION                    1
#     TITLE                           TOPIST scaled ionogram traces and electron density profiles
#     TEXT                            ISIS 2 was an ionospheric observatory instrumented with a sweep- and a fixed-frequency                 
#     TEXT                             ionosonde, a VLF receiver, energetic and soft particle detectors, an ion mass                         
#     TEXT                             spectrometer, an electrostatic probe, a retarding potential analyzer, a beacon                        
#     TEXT                             transmitter, a cosmic noise experiment, and two photometers. Two long crossed-dipole                  
#     TEXT                             antennas (73 and 18.7 m) were used for the sounding, VLF, and cosmic noise                            
#                                      experiments.                                                                                          
#                                     The spacecraft was spin-stabilized to about 2 rpm after antenna deployment.                            
#                                      There were two basic orientation modes for the spacecraft, cartwheel and orbit-aligned.               
#                                      The spacecraft operated approximately the same length of time in each mode,                           
#                                      remaining in one mode typically 3 to 5 months. The cartwheel mode with the                            
#                                      axis perpendicular to the orbit plane was made available to provide ram and                           
#                                      wake data for some experiments for each spin period, rather than for each orbit                       
#                                      period. Attitude and spin information was obtained from a three-axis magnetometer                     
#                                      and a sun sensor. Control of attitude and spin was possible by means of magnetic                      
#                                      torquing.                                                                                             
#                                     The experiment package also included a programmable tape recorder with a one                           
#                                      hour capacity. For non-recorded observations, data from satellite and subsatellite                    
#                                      regions were telemetered when the spacecraft was in the line of sight of a                            
#                                      telemetry station. Telemetry stations were located so that primary data coverage                      
#                                      was near the 80-deg-W meridian and near Hawaii, Singapore, Australia, England,                        
#                                      France, Norway, India, Japan, Antarctica, New Zealand, and Central Africa.                            
#                                      NASA support of the ISIS project was terminated on October 1, 1979.                                   
#                                     A significant amount of experimental data, however, was acquired after this                            
#                                      date by the Canadian project team. ISIS 2 operations were terminated in Canada                        
#                                      on March 9, 1984. The Radio Research Laboratories (Tokyo, Japan) then requested                       
#                                      and received permission to reactivate ISIS 2. Regular ISIS 2 operations were                          
#                                      started from Kashima, Japan, in early August 1984. ISIS 2 was deactivated effective                   
#                                      24, 1990. A data restoration effort began in the late 1990s and successfully                          
#                                      saved a considerable portion of the high-resolution data before the telemetry                         
#                                      tapes were discarted.                                                                                 
#                                     The data set was generated from the averaged ionogram binary data (SPIO-00318)                         
#                                      recorded by the Topside Sounder. The data are obtained with the TOPIST program,                       
#                                      which analyzes the data, automatically scales the ionogram traces and resonances,                     
#                                      and inverts the traces into an electron density profile. The same program is                          
#                                      available for use to hand-scale the data if desired. Output data items include                        
#                                      spacecraft position, electron density profile, assessment of quality, resonance                       
#                                      and cut-off frequencies, and both the O-trace and X-trace.                                            
#     ADID_REF                        NSSD0110
#     LOGICAL_FILE_ID                 i2_neprof_topist_00000000_v01
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE                  i2_neprof_topist
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE_DESCRIPTION      ISIS-2 TOPIST produced electron density profiles, of highest quality (quality                          
#                                      flag = 2 and 3                                                                                        
#     PI_NAME                         X. Huang and B. Reinisch
#     PI_AFFILIATION                  University of MassachusettsLowell
#     MISSION_GROUP                   ISIS
#                                     !___ITM Data including Earth Imaging and Ground-Based
#     INSTRUMENT_TYPE                 Imaging and Remote Sensing (ITM/Earth)
#     NSSDC_ID                        SPIO-00183
#     LINK_TEXT                       ISIS2 full listing
#     LINK_TITLE                      (shows data availability)
#     HTTP_LINK                       http://cdaweb.gsfc.nasa.gov/ISIS_ALOUETTE_DOCS/I2_NEPROF_TOPS_full_listing.txt
#
#  
# Key Parameter and Survey data (labels K0,K1,K2) are preliminary browse data.
# Generated by CDAWeb on: Thu Jan 15 18:05:06 2015

VariableDescription.Name: niLog10
VariableDescription.LongDescription: Log10 of Topside electron density along orbit in cm-3 (Image)
VariableDescription.Header:

#     TEXT                             antennas (73 and 18.7 m) were used for the sounding, VLF, and cosmic noise                            
#                                      experiments.                                                                                          
#                                     The spacecraft was spin-stabilized to about 2 rpm after antenna deployment.

#                                      The spacecraft operated approximately the same length of time in each mode,                           
#                                      remaining in one mode typically 3 to 5 months. The cartwheel mode with the                            
#                                      axis perpendicular to the orbit plane was made available to provide ram and                           
#                                      wake data for some experiments for each spin period, rather than for each orbit                       
#                                      period. Attitude and spin information was obtained from a three-axis magnetometer                     
#                                      and a sun sensor. Control of attitude and spin was possible by means of magnetic                      
#                                      torquing.                                                                                             
#                                     The experiment package also included a programmable tape recorder with a one                           
#                                      hour capacity. For non-recorded observations, data from satellite and subsatellite                    
#                                      regions were telemetered when the spacecraft was in the line of sight of a                            
#                                      telemetry station. Telemetry stations were located so that primary data coverage                      
#                                      was near the 80-deg-W meridian and near Hawaii, Singapore, Australia, England,                        
#                                      France, Norway, India, Japan, Antarctica, New Zealand, and Central Africa.

#                                      available for use to hand-scale the data if desired. Output data items include                        
#                                      spacecraft position, electron density profile, assessment of quality, resonance                       
#                                      and cut-off frequencies, and both the O-trace and X-trace.                                            
#     ADID_REF                        NSSD0110
#     LOGICAL_FILE_ID                 i2_neprof_topist_00000000_v01
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE                  i2_neprof_topist
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE_DESCRIPTION      ISIS-2 TOPIST produced electron density profiles, of highest quality (quality                          
#                                      flag = 2 and 3                                                                                        
#     PI_NAME                         X. Huang and B. Reinisch
#     PI_AFFILIATION                  University of MassachusettsLowell
#     MISSION_GROUP                   ISIS
#                                     !___ITM Data including Earth Imaging and Ground-Based
#     INSTRUMENT_TYPE                 Imaging and Remote Sensing (ITM/Earth)
#     NSSDC_ID                        SPIO-00183
#     LINK_TEXT                       ISIS2 full listing
#     LINK_TITLE                      (shows data availability)

VariableDescription.Name: sza
VariableDescription.Header:
# ******************************************************* 
#  WARNING: Increase time period selected for listing. 
# ******************************************************* 
# 
#              ************************************
#              *****    GLOBAL ATTRIBUTES    ******
#              ************************************
#
#     PROJECT                         ISIS>International Satellite for Ionosphere Studies
#                                     NSSDC>Archived Data
#     DISCIPLINE                      Space Physics>Ionospheric Science
#     SOURCE_NAME                     ISIS-2>International Satellite for Ionosphere Studies 1
#     DATA_TYPE                       NEPROF>Density Profiles
#     DESCRIPTOR                      TOPIST>Generated by TOPIST program, quality flags 2 and 3
#     DATA_VERSION                    1
#     TITLE                           TOPIST scaled ionogram traces and electron density profiles
#     TEXT                            ISIS 2 was an ionospheric observatory instrumented with a sweep- and a fixed-frequency                 
#     TEXT                             ionosonde, a VLF receiver, energetic and soft particle detectors, an ion mass                         
#     TEXT                             spectrometer, an electrostatic probe, a retarding potential analyzer, a beacon                        
#     TEXT                             transmitter, a cosmic noise experiment, and two photometers. Two long crossed-dipole                  
#     TEXT                             antennas (73 and 18.7 m) were used for the sounding, VLF, and cosmic noise                            
#                                      experiments.                                                                                          
#                                     The spacecraft was spin-stabilized to about 2 rpm after antenna deployment.                            
#                                      There were two basic orientation modes for the spacecraft, cartwheel and orbit-aligned.               
#                                      The spacecraft operated approximately the same length of time in each mode,                           
#                                      remaining in one mode typically 3 to 5 months. The cartwheel mode with the                            
#                                      axis perpendicular to the orbit plane was made available to provide ram and                           
#                                      wake data for some experiments for each spin period, rather than for each orbit                       
#                                      period. Attitude and spin information was obtained from a three-axis magnetometer                     
#                                      and a sun sensor. Control of attitude and spin was possible by means of magnetic                      
#                                      torquing.                                                                                             
#                                     The experiment package also included a programmable tape recorder with a one                           
#                                      hour capacity. For non-recorded observations, data from satellite and subsatellite                    
#                                      regions were telemetered when the spacecraft was in the line of sight of a                            
#                                      telemetry station. Telemetry stations were located so that primary data coverage                      
#                                      was near the 80-deg-W meridian and near Hawaii, Singapore, Australia, England,                        
#                                      France, Norway, India, Japan, Antarctica, New Zealand, and Central Africa.                            
#                                      NASA support of the ISIS project was terminated on October 1, 1979.                                   
#                                     A significant amount of experimental data, however, was acquired after this                            
#                                      date by the Canadian project team. ISIS 2 operations were terminated in Canada                        
#                                      on March 9, 1984. The Radio Research Laboratories (Tokyo, Japan) then requested                       
#                                      and received permission to reactivate ISIS 2. Regular ISIS 2 operations were                          
#                                      started from Kashima, Japan, in early August 1984. ISIS 2 was deactivated effective                   
#                                      24, 1990. A data restoration effort began in the late 1990s and successfully                          
#                                      saved a considerable portion of the high-resolution data before the telemetry                         
#                                      tapes were discarted.                                                                                 
#                                     The data set was generated from the averaged ionogram binary data (SPIO-00318)                         
#                                      recorded by the Topside Sounder. The data are obtained with the TOPIST program,                       
#                                      which analyzes the data, automatically scales the ionogram traces and resonances,                     
#                                      and inverts the traces into an electron density profile. The same program is                          
#                                      available for use to hand-scale the data if desired. Output data items include                        
#                                      spacecraft position, electron density profile, assessment of quality, resonance                       
#                                      and cut-off frequencies, and both the O-trace and X-trace.                                            
#     ADID_REF                        NSSD0110
#     LOGICAL_FILE_ID                 i2_neprof_topist_00000000_v01
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE                  i2_neprof_topist
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE_DESCRIPTION      ISIS-2 TOPIST produced electron density profiles, of highest quality (quality                          
#                                      flag = 2 and 3                                                                                        
#     PI_NAME                         X. Huang and B. Reinisch
#     PI_AFFILIATION                  University of MassachusettsLowell
#     MISSION_GROUP                   ISIS
#                                     !___ITM Data including Earth Imaging and Ground-Based
#     INSTRUMENT_TYPE                 Imaging and Remote Sensing (ITM/Earth)
#     NSSDC_ID                        SPIO-00183
#     LINK_TEXT                       ISIS2 full listing
#     LINK_TITLE                      (shows data availability)
#     HTTP_LINK                       http://cdaweb.gsfc.nasa.gov/ISIS_ALOUETTE_DOCS/I2_NEPROF_TOPS_full_listing.txt
#
#  
# Key Parameter and Survey data (labels K0,K1,K2) are preliminary browse data.
# Generated by CDAWeb on: Thu Jan 15 18:05:10 2015

VariableDescription.Name: L
VariableDescription.Header:
# ******************************************************* 
#  WARNING: Increase time period selected for listing. 
# ******************************************************* 
# 
#              ************************************
#              *****    GLOBAL ATTRIBUTES    ******
#              ************************************

#     PROJECT                         ISIS>International Satellite for Ionosphere Studies
#                                     NSSDC>Archived Data
#     DISCIPLINE                      Space Physics>Ionospheric Science
#     SOURCE_NAME                     ISIS-2>International Satellite for Ionosphere Studies 1
#     DATA_TYPE                       NEPROF>Density Profiles
#     DESCRIPTOR                      TOPIST>Generated by TOPIST program, quality flags 2 and 3
#     DATA_VERSION                    1
#     TITLE                           TOPIST scaled ionogram traces and electron density profiles
#     TEXT                            ISIS 2 was an ionospheric observatory instrumented with a sweep- and a fixed-frequency                 
#     TEXT                             ionosonde, a VLF receiver, energetic and soft particle detectors, an ion mass                         
#     TEXT                             spectrometer, an electrostatic probe, a retarding potential analyzer, a beacon                        
#     TEXT                             transmitter, a cosmic noise experiment, and two photometers. Two long crossed-dipole                  
#     TEXT                             antennas (73 and 18.7 m) were used for the sounding, VLF, and cosmic noise                            
#                                      experiments.                                                                                          
#                                     The spacecraft was spin-stabilized to about 2 rpm after antenna deployment.                            
#                                      There were two basic orientation modes for the spacecraft, cartwheel and orbit-aligned.               
#                                      The spacecraft operated approximately the same length of time in each mode,                           
#                                      remaining in one mode typically 3 to 5 months. The cartwheel mode with the                            
#                                      axis perpendicular to the orbit plane was made available to provide ram and                           
#                                      wake data for some experiments for each spin period, rather than for each orbit                       
#                                      period. Attitude and spin information was obtained from a three-axis magnetometer                     
#                                      and a sun sensor. Control of attitude and spin was possible by means of magnetic                      
#                                      torquing.                                                                                             
#                                     The experiment package also included a programmable tape recorder with a one                           
#                                      hour capacity. For non-recorded observations, data from satellite and subsatellite                    
#                                      regions were telemetered when the spacecraft was in the line of sight of a                            
#                                      telemetry station. Telemetry stations were located so that primary data coverage                      
#                                      was near the 80-deg-W meridian and near Hawaii, Singapore, Australia, England,                        
#                                      France, Norway, India, Japan, Antarctica, New Zealand, and Central Africa.                            
#                                      NASA support of the ISIS project was terminated on October 1, 1979.                                   
#                                     A significant amount of experimental data, however, was acquired after this                            
#                                      date by the Canadian project team. ISIS 2 operations were terminated in Canada                        
#                                      on March 9, 1984. The Radio Research Laboratories (Tokyo, Japan) then requested                       
#                                      and received permission to reactivate ISIS 2. Regular ISIS 2 operations were                          
#                                      started from Kashima, Japan, in early August 1984. ISIS 2 was deactivated effective                   
#                                      24, 1990. A data restoration effort began in the late 1990s and successfully                          
#                                      saved a considerable portion of the high-resolution data before the telemetry                         
#                                      tapes were discarted.                                                                                 
#                                     The data set was generated from the averaged ionogram binary data (SPIO-00318)                         
#                                      recorded by the Topside Sounder. The data are obtained with the TOPIST program,                       
#                                      which analyzes the data, automatically scales the ionogram traces and resonances,                     
#                                      and inverts the traces into an electron density profile. The same program is                          
#                                      available for use to hand-scale the data if desired. Output data items include                        
#                                      spacecraft position, electron density profile, assessment of quality, resonance                       
#                                      and cut-off frequencies, and both the O-trace and X-trace.                                            
#     ADID_REF                        NSSD0110
#     LOGICAL_FILE_ID                 i2_neprof_topist_00000000_v01
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE                  i2_neprof_topist
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE_DESCRIPTION      ISIS-2 TOPIST produced electron density profiles, of highest quality (quality                          
#                                      flag = 2 and 3                                                                                        
#     PI_NAME                         X. Huang and B. Reinisch
#     PI_AFFILIATION                  University of MassachusettsLowell
#     MISSION_GROUP                   ISIS
#                                     !___ITM Data including Earth Imaging and Ground-Based
#     INSTRUMENT_TYPE                 Imaging and Remote Sensing (ITM/Earth)
#     NSSDC_ID                        SPIO-00183
#     LINK_TEXT                       ISIS2 full listing
#     LINK_TITLE                      (shows data availability)
#     HTTP_LINK                       http://cdaweb.gsfc.nasa.gov/ISIS_ALOUETTE_DOCS/I2_NEPROF_TOPS_full_listing.txt
#
#  
# Key Parameter and Survey data (labels K0,K1,K2) are preliminary browse data.
# Generated by CDAWeb on: Thu Jan 15 18:05:10 2015

VariableDescription.Name: invdip
VariableDescription.LongDescription: Invdip - A new coordinate that combines Invariant Latitude and Dip Latitude
VariableDescription.Header:
# ******************************************************* 
#  WARNING: Increase time period selected for listing. 
# ******************************************************* 
# 
#              ************************************
#              *****    GLOBAL ATTRIBUTES    ******
#              ************************************
#
#     PROJECT                         ISIS>International Satellite for Ionosphere Studies
#                                     NSSDC>Archived Data
#     DISCIPLINE                      Space Physics>Ionospheric Science

VariableDescription.Name: mlon
VariableDescription.Header:
# ******************************************************* 
#  WARNING: Increase time period selected for listing. 
# ******************************************************* 
# 
#              ************************************
#              *****    GLOBAL ATTRIBUTES    ******
#              ************************************
#
#     PROJECT                         ISIS>International Satellite for Ionosphere Studies
#                                     NSSDC>Archived Data
#     DISCIPLINE                      Space Physics>Ionospheric Science
#     SOURCE_NAME                     ISIS-2>International Satellite for Ionosphere Studies 1
#     DATA_TYPE                       NEPROF>Density Profiles
#     DESCRIPTOR                      TOPIST>Generated by TOPIST program, quality flags 2 and 3
#     DATA_VERSION                    1
#     TITLE                           TOPIST scaled ionogram traces and electron density profiles
#     TEXT                            ISIS 2 was an ionospheric observatory instrumented with a sweep- and a fixed-frequency                 
#     TEXT                             ionosonde, a VLF receiver, energetic and soft particle detectors, an ion mass                         
#     TEXT                             spectrometer, an electrostatic probe, a retarding potential analyzer, a beacon                        
#     TEXT                             transmitter, a cosmic noise experiment, and two photometers. Two long crossed-dipole                  
#     TEXT                             antennas (73 and 18.7 m) were used for the sounding, VLF, and cosmic noise                            
#                                      experiments.                                                                                          
#                                     The spacecraft was spin-stabilized to about 2 rpm after antenna deployment.                            
#                                      There were two basic orientation modes for the spacecraft, cartwheel and orbit-aligned.               
#                                      The spacecraft operated approximately the same length of time in each mode,                           
#                                      remaining in one mode typically 3 to 5 months. The cartwheel mode with the                            
#                                      axis perpendicular to the orbit plane was made available to provide ram and                           
#                                      wake data for some experiments for each spin period, rather than for each orbit                       
#                                      period. Attitude and spin information was obtained from a three-axis magnetometer                     
#                                      and a sun sensor. Control of attitude and spin was possible by means of magnetic                      
#                                      torquing.                                                                                             
#                                     The experiment package also included a programmable tape recorder with a one                           
#                                      hour capacity. For non-recorded observations, data from satellite and subsatellite                    
#                                      regions were telemetered when the spacecraft was in the line of sight of a                            
#                                      telemetry station. Telemetry stations were located so that primary data coverage                      
#                                      was near the 80-deg-W meridian and near Hawaii, Singapore, Australia, England,                        
#                                      France, Norway, India, Japan, Antarctica, New Zealand, and Central Africa.                            
#                                      NASA support of the ISIS project was terminated on October 1, 1979.                                   
#                                     A significant amount of experimental data, however, was acquired after this                            
#                                      date by the Canadian project team. ISIS 2 operations were terminated in Canada                        
#                                      on March 9, 1984. The Radio Research Laboratories (Tokyo, Japan) then requested                       
#                                      and received permission to reactivate ISIS 2. Regular ISIS 2 operations were                          
#                                      started from Kashima, Japan, in early August 1984. ISIS 2 was deactivated effective                   
#                                      24, 1990. A data restoration effort began in the late 1990s and successfully                          
#                                      saved a considerable portion of the high-resolution data before the telemetry                         
#                                      tapes were discarted.                                                                                 
#                                     The data set was generated from the averaged ionogram binary data (SPIO-00318)                         
#                                      recorded by the Topside Sounder. The data are obtained with the TOPIST program,                       
#                                      which analyzes the data, automatically scales the ionogram traces and resonances,                     
#                                      and inverts the traces into an electron density profile. The same program is                          
#                                      available for use to hand-scale the data if desired. Output data items include                        
#                                      spacecraft position, electron density profile, assessment of quality, resonance                       
#                                      and cut-off frequencies, and both the O-trace and X-trace.                                            
#     ADID_REF                        NSSD0110
#     LOGICAL_FILE_ID                 i2_neprof_topist_00000000_v01
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE                  i2_neprof_topist
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE_DESCRIPTION      ISIS-2 TOPIST produced electron density profiles, of highest quality (quality                          
#                                      flag = 2 and 3                                                                                        
#     PI_NAME                         X. Huang and B. Reinisch
#     PI_AFFILIATION                  University of MassachusettsLowell
#     MISSION_GROUP                   ISIS
#                                     !___ITM Data including Earth Imaging and Ground-Based
#     INSTRUMENT_TYPE                 Imaging and Remote Sensing (ITM/Earth)
#     NSSDC_ID                        SPIO-00183

#     LINK_TITLE                      (shows data availability)
#     HTTP_LINK                       http://cdaweb.gsfc.nasa.gov/ISIS_ALOUETTE_DOCS/I2_NEPROF_TOPS_full_listing.txt
